awd_titl_txt: Atmospheric Dynamics with Phase Changes and Extreme Rainfall Events
awd_abstract_narration:
Water vapor in the atmosphere plays a critical role in extreme weather events. A pressing challenge for the world scientific community, and the topic of this award, is to better understand the dynamical role of water and its influence on atmospheric energetics. A better understanding would help shape future social and economic policy decisions. In particular, more accurate prediction of extreme rainfall events has the potential to save human lives, as well as to better mitigate hundreds of billions of dollars in disaster losses. In addition to advancing scientific and mathematical understanding, the proposed activities also support the training of junior researchers with interdisciplinary expertise. To position these new researchers for future success, mentoring will be provided by the PIs to develop the knowledge, skills and experience necessary for integrating mathematics with the atmospheric sciences. For example, modern weather prediction relies on incorporation of physical insight and observational data into numerical algorithms to solve the mathematical description of atmospheric dynamics in terms of equations. Furthermore, beyond weather predictions themselves are the users of weather predictions, such as government agencies, the insurance industry and other businesses.  To assess the risks associated with weather events and their impacts, technical skills are needed in both mathematics and atmospheric sciences.

Phase changes of water are a key part of the hydrological cycle. Of particular importance for weather is the phase change from water vapor to liquid water within clouds, and the subsequent formation of precipitation. The heat released from these phase changes can drive atmospheric circulations, and, conversely, atmospheric circulations shape the formation of cloud patterns and precipitation. This coupling between water and atmospheric fluid dynamics is nonlinear and remains a challenge to understand. The award activities aim to improve our fundamental understanding--both mathematical and physical--of moist atmospheric dynamics with phase changes, with attention to high precipitation events. To meet this aim, a hierarchy of partial differential equations will be studied in order to elucidate foundation aspects of such flows, such as: the influence of waves on large-scale balanced flows; the transfer of energy between kinetic, potential and latent energies; and the propagation of sharp interfaces between unsaturated and saturated flow regions. The methods to be used include asymptotical analysis of wave dynamics in the presence of phase changes, construction of discontinuous analytical solutions, observational data analysis based on energy principles and balance relations, and numerical modeling. Extreme rainfall events in the mid-latitudes are always associated with large poleward fluxes of moisture originating from the tropics, such as the structures called 'atmospheric rivers.' The phenomena of atmospheric rivers and their associated jet streaks are one of the central observations proposed for application studies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main topic of the project was atmospheric dynamics with phase changes of water. Examples include clouds, rainfall, and precipitation, which represent changes of water from the gas phase (as water vapor) to its liquid or solid phases. Scientific understanding is lacking for atmospheric dynamics with clouds, in comparison to understanding of atmospheric dynamics without clouds. Improved understanding can potentially lead to improvements in weather forecasting and prediction of clouds and rainfall.

Intellectual Merit:

New theoretical understanding was achieved in several ways.  New conservation laws were uncovered, now including the effects of clouds, as extensions of nearly century-old conservation laws that hold without clouds. In particular, these are extensions of Ertel's theorem for potential vorticity conservation and Kelvin's circulation theorem. Also, a new concept of slow and fast, or balanced and unbalanced, components of moisture was introduced and investigated. This extends the well-known concept of slow-fast or balanced-unbalanced decomposition of velocity and temperature, and now defines a similar concept for moisture. In addition, a new decomposition of energy was derived, and it highlights the component of energy that is associated with slowly evolving (balanced) moisture and that is activated when a cloud forms. As another theoretical result, a new mathematical theorem was proved that characterizes the smoothness of velocity and other variables at the edge of a cloud edge. This theorem holds in the limit of rapid rotation and strong stratification, i.e., when the Earth's rotation rate is faster than the atmospheric circulations, and when the temperature of the atmosphere is strongly stratified or changing strongly at different altitudes.

Computer simulations were conducted in order to illustrate the new theoretical findings and also to investigate some scientific questions. For example, intense precipitation events were simulated as examples of extreme events using the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model, and the balanced and unbalanced, or slow and fast, components of moisture were evaluated and described. Computer simulations were also used for the first computational illustration of the new conservation law for potential vorticity described above. In addition, computer simulations were used to investigate the influence of fast waves in the limit (defined above) of rapid rotation and strong stratification. In particular, in this limit, it was found that the slow and fast components of the atmosphere become coupled in the presence of clouds. This is in contrast to a well-known theorem for the decoupling of the slow component from the fast component in this limit, when clouds are absent. 

Broader Impacts:

The projects involved the training of 2 PhD students and a postdoctoral researchers in interdisciplinary research in applied mathematics and atmospheric science. An undergraduate student researcher was also a collaborator and co-author for one project, and he then went on to pursue a PhD in applied and computational mathematics.

The theoretical advances of the project may have an impact on weather forecasting and data assimilaton, which is the process of merging observational data into a weather forecast. Moisture, clouds, and precipitation are important quantities that influence society in many ways. Also, weather forecasts utilize the concepts of slow and fast, or balanced and unbalanced, components of the atmopshere. Consequently, new understanding of balanced-unbalanced components, in the presence of clouds, can potentially influence methods for weather forecasting and data assimilation.
